introduction.p: A three hour local competition was held on December 5, 2020 in place of the Putnam, which was delayed until February 2021.

statement.p: Let R denote the set of points (x, y) satisfying x^2 - 4 \lvert x \rvert +y^2 + 3 \leq 0. What is the area of R?

solution.p: If x \geq 0, then the inequality is (x-2)^2 +y^2 \le 1, which is a disk of radius 1 entirely to the right of the y axis, which has area \pi. If x \lt 0, then the inequality is (x+2)^2 +y^2 \le 1 which is a disk of radius 1 entirely to the left of the y axis, which has area \pi.

statement.p: Let f(n) be the number of n-letter words that can formed with the letters A,B,C and such that the letter A occurs an even number of times. For example, when n = 1, there are 2 such words, namely B,C so f (1) = 2; when n = 2, there are 5 such words, namely AA,BB,BC,CB,CC, so f(2) = 5. Find, with proof, a simple formula for f(n). (The formula should not involve a summation.)

solution.p: One solution to this problem is to identify that f(n) is the coefficient of x^n in (1+x+x^2+x^3+\dots)^2(1+x^2+x^4+x^6+\dots)= \frac{1}{(1-x)^3(1+x)}

statement.p: An equilateral triangle in the first quadrant has vertices at the points (0, 0), (x_1, 5), and (x_2, 12). What is the ordered pair (x_1, x_2)? Show your work.

solution.p: If we consider the points as complex numbers, then x_2 + 12\,i must be equal to the product (x_1 + 5\,i)(\cos{(\pi/3)} + \sin{(\pi/3)} \,i), This lets you solve for the unknowns.

statement.p:
A square matrix A has a "square root" if there exists a matrix B such that B^2 = A.
Prove that \left( \begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \\ \end{array} \right) has no square root.
Determine, with proof, whether \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ \end{array} \right) has a square root.

solution.p: Under the assumptions of the problem, the arithmetic mean of the numbers is \frac{ x_1 + x_2 + \dots + x_n}{n} = \frac{1}{n} and the harmonic mean is \frac{n}{ \frac{1}{x_1}+\frac{1}{x_2} + \dots + \frac{1}{x_n}} = \frac{n}{9}. Since the harmonic mean is always less than or equal to the arithmetic mean, it must be that \frac{n}{9} \leq \frac{1}{n} or n \leq 3. This leaves us with the only possibilities for n being 2 or 3 since 1 is clearly impossible. If n=3, the two means are equal and the only way that can happen is if all the x_i are equal. That give us the first solution. For the second, we have two numbers a and b such that a + b = 9 \quad\textrm{and }\quad \frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}=1. Solving this system of equations give us the other two solutions.

statement.p: At the Hard Math Casino there is a wheel with the numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4. When you spin the wheel, a pointer points to one of the numbers, each with probability \frac{1}{4}. You are given a “target number” which is a positive integer n. You spin the wheel repeatedly, adding the resulting numbers and win the game if you get a sum of exactly n. Let p(n) be the probability of winning if your target number is n. What is lim_{n\rightarrow \infty}\, p(n)?
